MISRA12_20.3.name: Published Standards/MISRA C 2012/20.3 The #include directive shall be followed by either a <filename> or "filename" sequence

html: This check is automatically run during strict analysis, any violations will be reported as analysis errors.
This rule applies after macro replacement has been performed.
The behaviour is undefined if a #include directive does not use one of the following forms:
#include BASE EXT          /* Non-compliant - strings are concatenated
#include "./include/cpu.h" /* Compliant - filename may include a path */

MISRA08_15-3-7.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/15-3-7 Catch-All Statement Before Last

html: This check is automatically run during strict analysis, any violations will be reported as analysis errors.
Where multiple handlers are provided in a single try-catch statement or function-try-block, any ellipsis (catch-all) handler shall occur last.
If the catch-all handler is found before any other handler, that behaviour will be performed. Any handlers after the catch-all are unreachable code and can never be executed.
catch ( int32_t i )   // Non-compliant - handler will never be called

MISRA08_16-2-6.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/16-2-6 The #include directive shall be followed by either a <filename> or "filename" sequence

html: This check is automatically run during strict analysis, any violations will be reported as analysis errors.
These are the only forms for the #include directive permitted by ISO/IEC 14882:2003 [1].

MISRA04_19.3.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C 2004/19.3 The #include directive shall be followed by either a <filename> or "filename" sequence

html: This check is automatically run during strict analysis, any violations will be reported as analysis errors.

MISRA08_0-3-1.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/0-3-1 Minimization of run-time failures shall be ensured by the use of static analysis tools

html: This check is automatically run during strict analysis, any violations will be reported as analysis errors.
Minimization of run-time failures shall be ensured by the use of at least one of:
(c) explicit coding of checks to handle run-time faults.
Run-time checking is an issue (not specific to C++) to which developers need to pay special
attention, especially as the C++ language is weak in its provision of any run-time checking. C++
implementations are not required to perform many of the dynamic checks that are necessary for
robust software. It is therefore an issue that C++ developers need to consider carefully, adding
dynamic checks to code wherever there is the potential for run-time errors to occur.
Where expressions consist only of values within a well-defined range, a run-time check may
not be necessary, provided it can be demonstrated that for all values within the defined range
the exception cannot occur. Such a demonstration, if used, should be documented along with
the assumptions on which it depends. However, if adopting this approach, be very careful about
subsequent modifications of the code that may invalidate the assumptions, or of the assumptions
The following notes give some guidance on areas where consideration needs to be given to the
This includes errors occurring in the evaluation of expressions, such as overflow, underflow,
division by zero or loss of significant bits through shifting.
In considering integer overflow, note that unsigned integer calculations do not strictly
overflow (producing undefined values), but the values wrap around (producing defined, but
Ensure that when an address is calculated dynamically the computed address is reasonable
and points somewhere meaningful. In particular it should be ensured that if a pointer points
within a structure or array, then when the pointer has been incremented or otherwise altered
it still points to the same structure or array. See Rule 5-0-15, Rule 5-0-16, Rule 5-0-17
and Rule 5-0-18 for restrictions on pointer arithmetic.
Ensure that array indices are within the bounds of the array size before using them to index
Where a function returns a pointer and that pointer is subsequently de-referenced the
program should first check that the pointer is not NULL. Within a function, it is relatively
straightforward to reason about which pointers may or may not hold NULL values. Across
function boundaries, especially when calling functions defined in other source files or
libraries, it is much more difficult.
// Given a pointer to a message, check the message header and return
// a pointer to the body of the message or NULL if the message is
The techniques that will be employed to minimize run-time failures should be planned and
documented, e.g. in design standards, test plans, static analysis configuration files, code review

MISRA04_19.11.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C 2004/19.11 All macro identifiers in preprocessor directives shall be defined before use, except in #ifdef and #ifndef preprocessor directives and the defined() operator

html: If an attempt is made to use an identifier in a preprocessor directive, and that
identifier has not been defined, the preprocessor will sometimes not give any
warning but will assume the value zero. #ifdef, #ifndef and
defined() are provided to test the existence of a macro, and are
#if x < 0 /* x assumed to be zero as it is not defined */
Consideration should be given to the use of a #ifdef test before an
Note that preprocessing identifiers may be defined either by use of
#define directives or by options specified at compiler invocation.
However, the use of the #define directive is preferred.

MISRA23_8.2.1.name: Published Standards/MISRA C++ 2023/8.2.1 A virtual base class shall only be cast to a derived class by means of dynamic_cast

html: This check is automatically run during strict analysis, any violations will be reported as analysis errors.
The behaviour when casting from a virtual base class to a derived class is only well defined when
dynamic_cast is used, whilst the use of the other casts can result in undefined behaviour.
Since C++17, a static_cast from a virtual base class is now ill-formed, but some compilers may not yet
issue a diagnostic. This rule ensures that all cases are detected.
D *pD2 = dynamic_cast<D*>(pB); // Compliant, but pD2 may be NULL
D & D3 = dynamic_cast<D&>(*pB); // Compliant, but may throw an exception

MISRA04_21.1.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C 2004/21.1 Minimisation of run-time failures shall be ensured by the use of at least one of: (a) static analysis tools/techniques; (b) dynamic analysis tools/techniques; (c) explicit coding of checks to handle run-time faults.

html: This check is automatically run during strict analysis, any violations will be reported as analysis errors.
Minimisation of run-time failures shall be ensured by the use of at least one of
(c) explicit coding of checks to handle run-time faults.
Run-time checking is an issue, which is not specific to C, but it is an issue which C programmers
need to pay special attention to. This is because the C language is weak in its provision of any
run-time checking. C implementations are not required to perform many of the dynamic checks
that are necessary for robust software. It is therefore an issue that C programmers need to consider
carefully, adding dynamic checks to code wherever there is potential for run-time errors to occur.
Where expressions consist only of values within a well-defined range, a run-time check may
not be necessary, provided it can be demonstrated that for all values within the defined range
the exception cannot occur. Such a demonstration, if used, should be documented along with
the assumptions on which it depends. However if adopting this approach, be very careful about
subsequent modifications of the code which may invalidate the assumptions, or of the assumptions
The following notes give some guidance on areas where consideration needs to be given to the
This includes errors occurring in the evaluation of expressions, such as overflow,
underflow, divide by zero or loss of significant bits through shifting.
In considering integer overflow, note that unsigned integer calculations do not strictly
overflow (producing undefined values), but the values wrap around (producing defined,
Ensure that when an address is calculated dynamically the computed address is reasonable
and points somewhere meaningful. In particular it should be ensured that if a pointer
points within a structure or array, then when the pointer has been incremented or otherwise
altered it still points to the same structure or array. See restrictions on pointer arithmetic
Ensure that array indices are within the bounds of the array size before using them to
Where a function returns a pointer and that pointer is subsequently de-referenced the
program should first check that the pointer is not NULL. Within a function, it is relatively
straightforward to reason about which pointers may or may not hold NULL values. Across
function boundaries, especially when calling functions defined in other source files or
libraries, it is much more difficult.
<pre><code language="C++">/* Given a pointer to a message, check the message header and return
a pointer to the body of the message or NULL if the message is
The techniques that will be employed to minimise run-time failures should be planned and
documented, e.g. in design standards, test plans, static analysis configuration files, code review

MISRA08_16-1-2.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/16-1-2 All #else, #elif and #endif preprocessor directives shall reside in the same file as the #if, #ifdef or #ifndef directive to which they are related

html: This check is automatically run during strict analysis, any violations will be reported as analysis errors.
Confusion can arise when blocks of code are included or excluded by the use of conditional compilation
directives which are spread over multiple files. Requiring that a #if directive be terminated within the
same file reduces the visual complexity of the code and the chance that errors will be made during maintenance.
Note: #if directives may be used within included files provided they are terminated within the same file.

MISRA12_20.14.name: Published Standards/MISRA C 2012/20.14 All #else, #elif and #endif preprocessor directives shall reside in the same file as the #if, #ifdef or #ifndef directive to which they are related

html: This check is automatically run during strict analysis, any violations will be reported as analysis errors.
Confusion can arise when blocks of code are included or excluded by the use of conditional compilation
directives which are spread over multiple files. Requiring that a #if directive be terminated within the
same file reduces the visual complexity of the code and the chance that errors will be made during maintenance.
Note: #if directives may be used within included files provided they are terminated within the same file.

MISRA23_20.14.name: Published Standards/MISRA C 2023/20.14 All #else, #elif and #endif preprocessor directives shall reside in the same file as the #if, #ifdef or #ifndef directive to which they are related

html: This check is automatically run during strict analysis, any violations will be reported as analysis errors.
Confusion can arise when blocks of code are included or excluded by the use of conditional compilation
directives which are spread over multiple files. Requiring that a #if directive be terminated within the
same file reduces the visual complexity of the code and the chance that errors will be made during maintenance.
Note: #if directives may be used within included files provided they are terminated within the same file.

MISRA23_11.10.name: Published Standards/MISRA C 2023/11.10 The _Atomic qualifier shall not be applied to the incomplete type void

html: This check is automatically run during strict analysis, any violations will be reported as analysis errors.
The C Standard does not explicitly prohibit usage of the type void with the _Atomic qualifier. However,
it does not provide a guarantee that a pointer to _Atomic void has any particular size or alignment
requirement, so it cannot be assumed that is the same as for a pointer to an arbitrary type _Atomic T,
and the behaviour of type conversion between them may be undefined.

MISRA04_19.17.name: Published Standards/MISRA C 2004/20.14 All #else, #elif and #endif preprocessor directives shall reside in the same file as the #if, #ifdef or #ifndef directive to which they are related

html: This check is automatically run during strict analysis, any violations will be reported as analysis errors.
Confusion can arise when blocks of code are included or excluded by the use of conditional compilation
directives which are spread over multiple files. Requiring that a #if directive be terminated within the
same file reduces the visual complexity of the code and the chance that errors will be made during maintenance.
Note: #if directives may be used within included files provided they are terminated within the same file.

MISRA23_19.1.2.name: Published Standards/MISRA C++ 2023/19.1.2 All #else, #elif and #endif preprocessor directives shall reside in the same file as the #if, #ifdef or #ifndef directive to which they are related

html: This check is automatically run during strict analysis, any violations will be reported as analysis errors.
Confusion can arise when code blocks are included or excluded by the use of conditional compilation
directives which are spread over multiple files. Requiring that a #if directive be terminated within
the same file reduces the visual complexity of the code and the chance that errors will be made during maintenance.
1. #if directives may be used within included files, provided they are terminated within the same file.
2. It is not clear from the C++ Standard whether such constructs are allowed. Some compilers
do require that a #endif (etc.) must be in the same file as the associated #if (etc.), and
all compilers tested raise an error if this is not the case. However, this requirement is not
explicitly expressed in the C++ Standard, and there is a reading of the grammar that would allow
it. This rule aims to prevent this construct, should any compiler actually allow it.

MISRA04_1.5.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C 2004/1.5 Floating-point implementations should comply with a defined floating-point standard

html: Floating-point implementations should comply with a defined floating-point standard

MISRA04_3.1.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C 2004/3.1 All usage of implementation-defined behaviour shall be documented

html: All usage of implementation-defined behaviour shall be documented

MISRA04_3.2.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C 2004/3.2 The character set and the corresponding encoding shall be documented

html: The character set and the corresponding encoding shall be documented

MISRA04_3.3.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C 2004/3.3 The implementation of integer division in the chosen compiler should be determined, documented and taken into account

html: The implementation of integer division in the chosen compiler should be determined, documented and taken into account

MISRA04_3.4.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C 2004/3.4 All uses of the #pragma directive shall be documented and explained

html: All uses of the #pragma directive shall be documented and explained

MISRA04_3.5.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C 2004/3.5 The implementation defined behaviour and packing of bitfields shall be documented if being relied upon

html: The implementation defined behaviour and packing of bitfields shall be documented if being relied upon

MISRA04_3.6.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C 2004/3.6 All libraries used in production code shall be written to comply with the provisions of this document, and shall have been subject to appropriate validation

html: All libraries used in production code shall be written to comply with the provisions of this document, and shall have been subject to appropriate validation

MISRA04_9.1.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C 2004/9.1 All automatic variables shall have been assigned a value before being used

html: All automatic variables shall have been assigned a value before being used

MISRA04_16.10.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C 2004/16.10 Functions shall not be defined with variable numbers of arguments

html: Functions shall not be defined with variable numbers of arguments

MISRA08_0-1-6.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/0-1-6 A project shall not contain instances of non-volatile variables being given values that are never subsequently used

html: A project shall not contain instances of non-volatile variables being given values that are never subsequently used

MISRA08_0-2-1.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/0-2-1 An object shall not be assigned to an overlapping object

html: An object shall not be assigned to an overlapping object

MISRA08_0-4-1.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/0-4-1 Use of scaled-integer or fixed-point arithmetic shall be documented

html: Use of scaled-integer or fixed-point arithmetic shall be documented

MISRA08_0-4-2.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/0-4-2 Use of floating-point arithmetic shall be documented

html: Use of floating-point arithmetic shall be documented

MISRA08_0-4-3.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/0-4-3 Floating-point implementations shall comply with a defined floating-point standard

html: Floating-point implementations shall comply with a defined floating-point standard

MISRA08_1-0-1.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/1-0-1 All code shall conform to ISO/IEC 14882:2003 "The C++ Standard Incorporating Technical Corrigendum 1"

html: All code shall conform to ISO/IEC 14882:2003 "The C++ Standard Incorporating Technical Corrigendum 1"

MISRA08_1-0-2.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/1-0-2 Multiple compilers shall only be used if they have a common, defined interface

html: Multiple compilers shall only be used if they have a common, defined interface

MISRA08_1-0-3.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/1-0-3 The implementation of integer division in the chosen compiler shall be determined and documented

html: The implementation of integer division in the chosen compiler shall be determined and documented

MISRA08_2-2-1.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/2-2-1 The character set and the corresponding encoding shall be documented

html: The character set and the corresponding encoding shall be documented

MISRA08_2-10-6.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/2-10-6 If an identifier refers to a type, it shall not also refer to an object or a function in the same scope

html: If an identifier refers to a type, it shall not also refer to an object or a function in the same scope

MISRA08_5-0-13.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/5-0-13 The condition of an if-statement and the condition of an iteration-statement shall have type bool

html: The condition of an if-statement and the condition of an iteration-statement shall have type bool

MISRA08_5-0-15.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/5-0-15 Array indexing shall be the only form of pointer arithmetic

html: Array indexing shall be the only form of pointer arithmetic

MISRA08_5-0-16.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/5-0-16 A pointer operand and any pointer resulting from pointer arithmetic using that operand shall both address elements of the same array

html: A pointer operand and any pointer resulting from pointer arithmetic using that operand shall both address elements of the same array

MISRA08_5-2-1.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/5-2-1 Each operand of a logical && or || shall be a postfix expression

html: Each operand of a logical && or || shall be a postfix expression

MISRA08_5-2-2.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/5-2-2 A pointer to a virtual base class shall only be cast to a pointer to a derived class by means of dynamic_cast

html: A pointer to a virtual base class shall only be cast to a pointer to a derived class by means of dynamic_cast

MISRA08_5-2-4.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/5-2-4 C-style casts (other than void casts) and functional notation casts (other than explicit constructor calls) shall not be used

html: C-style casts (other than void casts) and functional notation casts (other than explicit constructor calls) shall not be used

MISRA08_5-2-7.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/5-2-7 An object with pointer type shall not be converted to an unrelated pointer type, either directly or indirectly

html: An object with pointer type shall not be converted to an unrelated pointer type, either directly or indirectly

MISRA08_5-3-2.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/5-3-2 The unary minus operator shall not be applied to an expression whose underlying type is unsigned

html: The unary minus operator shall not be applied to an expression whose underlying type is unsigned

MISRA08_5-14-1.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/5-14-1 The right hand operand of a logical && or || operator shall not contain side effects

html: The right hand operand of a logical && or || operator shall not contain side effects

MISRA08_5-17-1.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/5-17-1 The semantic equivalence between a binary operator and its assignment operator form shall be preserved

html: The semantic equivalence between a binary operator and its assignment operator form shall be preserved

MISRA08_5-18-1.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/5-18-1 The comma operator shall not be used

html: The comma operator shall not be used

MISRA08_5-19-1.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/5-19-1 Evaluation of constant unsigned integer expressions should not lead to wrap-around

html: Evaluation of constant unsigned integer expressions should not lead to wrap-around

MISRA08_6-2-1.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/6-2-1 Assignment operators shall not be used in sub-expressions

html: Assignment operators shall not be used in sub-expressions

MISRA08_6-4-3.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/6-4-3 A switch statement shall be a well-formed switch statement

html: A switch statement shall be a well-formed switch statement

MISRA08_6-4-7.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/6-4-7 The condition of a switch statement shall not have bool type

html: The condition of a switch statement shall not have bool type

MISRA08_6-6-3.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/6-6-3 The continue statement shall only be used within a well-formed for loop

html: The continue statement shall only be used within a well-formed for loop

MISRA08_7-4-1.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/7-4-1 All usage of assembler shall be documented

html: All usage of assembler shall be documented

MISRA08_7-5-3.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/7-5-3 A function shall not return a reference or a pointer to a parameter that is passed by reference or const reference

html: A function shall not return a reference or a pointer to a parameter that is passed by reference or const reference

MISRA08_10-2-1.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/10-2-1 All accessible entity names within a multiple inheritance hierarchy should be unique

html: All accessible entity names within a multiple inheritance hierarchy should be unique

MISRA08_12-8-2.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/12-8-2 The copy assignment operator shall be declared protected or private in an abstract class

html: The copy assignment operator shall be declared protected or private in an abstract class

MISRA08_14-5-1.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/14-5-1 A non-member generic function shall only be declared in a namespace that is not an associated namespace

html: A non-member generic function shall only be declared in a namespace that is not an associated namespace

MISRA08_14-6-1.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/14-6-1 In a class template with a dependent base, any name that may be found in that dependent base shall be referred to using a qualified-id or this->

html: In a class template with a dependent base, any name that may be found in that dependent base shall be referred to using a qualified-id or this->

MISRA08_14-6-2.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/14-6-2 The function or operator chosen by overload resolution shall resolve to a function declared previously in the translation unit

html: The function or operator chosen by overload resolution shall resolve to a function declared previously in the translation unit

MISRA08_14-7-2.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/14-7-2 For any given template specialization, an explicit instantiation of the template with the template-arguments used in the specialization shall not render the program ill-formed

html: For any given template specialization, an explicit instantiation of the template with the template-arguments used in the specialization shall not render the program ill-formed

MISRA08_14-7-3.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/14-7-3 All partial and explicit specializations for a template shall be declared in the same file as the declaration of their primary template

html: All partial and explicit specializations for a template shall be declared in the same file as the declaration of their primary template

MISRA08_14-8-2.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/14-8-2 The viable function set for a function call should either contain no function specializations, or only contain function specializations

html: The viable function set for a function call should either contain no function specializations, or only contain function specializations

MISRA08_15-0-1.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/15-0-1 Exceptions shall only be used for error handling

html: Exceptions shall only be used for error handling

MISRA08_15-0-3.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/15-0-3 Control shall not be transferred into a try or catch block using a goto or a switch statement

html: Control shall not be transferred into a try or catch block using a goto or a switch statement

MISRA08_15-3-4.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/15-3-4 Each exception explicitly thrown in the code shall have a handler of a compatible type in all call paths that could lead to that point

html: Each exception explicitly thrown in the code shall have a handler of a compatible type in all call paths that could lead to that point

MISRA08_15-5-3.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/15-5-3 The terminate() function shall not be called implicitly

html: The terminate() function shall not be called implicitly

MISRA08_16-6-1.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/16-6-1 All uses of the #pragma directive shall be documented

html: All uses of the #pragma directive shall be documented

MISRA08_17-0-4.name: Published Standards/MISRA-C++ 2008/17-0-4 All library code shall conform to MISRA C++

html: All library code shall conform to MISRA C++
